data: Small altar of Zeus Soter Hieron

A small horned altar of limestone, damaged across the top from front to back between the horns. The altar has mouldings around the base and the top on all four sides, with a smooth field in between on all four faces
Two lines of Greek text in the field on the front face of the altar (8.5 cm wide x 2.5 cm high)

The first three letters are more deeply engraved, the remaining letters are little more than scratched in the surface with a sharp point, and are increasingly irregular in form. Omega is open; top and bottom bars of sigma tending slightly apart; omicron is small than other letters; epsilon has horizontals of equal length.
Found in excavation in Giardino Spagna (1948), area of the modern Umberto I hospital, Siracusa
Photo J. Prag, Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.
Association pour l’encouragement des études greques, « Bulletin épigraphique », Bulletin épigraphique, 1888, http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/797735566

Accademia nazionale dei Lincei, Istituto nazionale di archeologia e storia dell’arte (Italy), e Reale Accademia d’Italia, «Notizie degli scavi di antichità», Notizie degli Scavi di Antichità, 1876, http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1646037
Per la storia dei culti in Sicilia
Giacomo Manganaro, «Per la storia dei culti in Sicilia», La Parola del Passato 20, fasc. 101 (1965): 163–78
Syrakus unter Agathokles und Hieron II
C. Lehmler, Syrakus Unter Agathokles Und Hieron II (Frankfurt am Main: Verlag Antike, 2005)
Per una revisione dei documenti epigrafici siracusani pertinenti al regno di Ierone II

Alessia Dimartino, ‘Per Una Revisione Dei Documenti Epigrafici Siracusani Pertinenti al Regno Di Ierone II’, in Guerra e Pace in Sicilia e Nel Mediterraneo Antico (VIII-III Sec. a.C.). Arte, Prassi e Teoria Della Pace e Della Guerra, ed. C. Michelini, vol. 2, 2 vols, Atti Elimi V (Pisa: Edizioni della Normale, 2006), 703–17
A Syracusan Private Altar and the Development of Ruler-Cult in Hellenistic Sicily
J. Serrati, ‘A Syracusan Private Altar and the Development of Ruler-Cult in Hellenistic Sicily’, Historia 57, no. 1 (2008): 80–91
Mégara Hyblaea. 7, La ville classique, hellénistique et romaine
Henry Tréziny, Mégara Hyblaea. 7, La Ville Classique, Hellénistique et Romaine, CEFR 1/7 (Rome: École française de Rome, 2018)
Διὸς Σωτῆ ρος Ἱέρωνος
small altar of zeus soter hieron
ISic002955. Small altar of Zeus Soter Hieron

1Διὸς Σωτῆ-
2ρος Ἱέρωνος

1ΔΙΟΣΣΩΤΗ
2ΡΟΣΙΕΡΩΝΟΣ

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text from autopsy

English translation

Altar of Zeus Soter of Hieron / Altar of Zeus Soter (dedicated by) Hieron / Altar of Zeus Soter Hieron

commentary

Interpretation of this small altar is difficult and important. Small domestic altars of this sort are common, with the name of the divinity to which it is dedicated often in the genitive. The combination of Zeus Soter (Zeus the Saviour, a common form of Zeus; pot sherd graffiti on display in the same gallery as this altar in the Siracusa Archaeological museum attest to the existence of Zeus Soter cult in Hellenistic Syracuse; also possibly attested at Megara Hyblaea (Treziny 2018: 221)) together with the name Hieron encourages the idea that this altar reflects the existence of a ruler cult for Hieron II of Syracuse, with Hieron assimilated to Zeus Soter. The form of the letters is compatible with a third-century date. However, the presence of all three words in the genitive in this way is not typical and is awkward grammatically and lacks easy parallels. Additionally, there is no evidence for official ruler cult for Hieron II of Syracuse (see the extensive discussion in Habicht 1970 and Serrati 2008 in particular). The nature of the object (small domestic altar) together with the rather crude form of the inscription both suggest a private domestic context; however, the existence of such private veneration would more commonly be assumed on the basis of public cult.
